abstract.text: We present a search for Physics beyond the Standard Model (SM) in final states with a Z boson, jets and missing transverse energy, using a data sample collected in 2011 by the CMS detector at the Large Hadron Collider corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 2.1 fb −1 .
This final state is predicted in several models of Physics beyond the SM, including supersymmetry.
A novel analysis method is exploited, the Jet-Z Balance method, and a precise determination of the total SM background is obtained using a control sample from data.

In the absence of any significant excess beyond the SM background, upper limits are set on simple models of supersymmetry, and further information is provided to allow confrontation of other models to these results.

body_text.text: We describe a search [1] for Physics beyond the Standard Model (BSM) in a sample of pp collisions collected by the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) detector [2] at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), at a center-of-mass energy of 7 TeV.
The size of the data sample corresponds to 2.1 fb −1 .
We search for final states with a Z boson, jets and missing energy (E miss T ) where the Z boson decays to electron or muon pairs.
This final state is a clean and distinct signature present in many models of BSM Physics, in particular supersymmetry (SUSY) [3,4].
The most significant Standard Model (SM) backgrounds in this final state are Z + jets processes and tt production.
The former is the most challenging since it peaks in the mass distribution of the two leptons and can have apparent missing energy due to detector resolution and reconstruction effects.
The Jet-Z balance (JZB) method has been devised to predict the contribution from Z +jets events [5].
We use the flavor symmetry of tt decays, as well as dilepton invariant mass side-band regions to predict the contribution from tt events.
We select events with at least three central jets with transverse momentum p T > 30 GeV and two opposite-sign leptons with p T > 20 GeV.
The JZB variable is defined as the difference between the p T of the vectorial sum of all jets and the p T of the Z boson candidate:

The JZB variable has a strong discriminating power between instrumental MET events (which populate the left and the right side evenly) and real MET events, like signal events, which are shifted to the right.
The JZB distribution is shown in Fig. 1.
A low-, a mid-, and a high-JZB search region are defined by requiring JZB > 50GeV, JZB > 100GeV, and JZB > 150GeV, respectively.

Three control regions are used to predict the contribution of flavor-symmetric backgrounds (mainly coming from tt processes):

opposite-flavor events compatible with the Z boson mass hypothesis (JZB OFZP ) opposite-flavor events in the side-band of the Z boson mass (JZB OFSB ) and same-flavor events in the same side-band region (JZB SFSB )

The contribution from flavor-symmetric backgrounds is computed as the average of the three control regions, as they provide an independent estimate of the same background process.
The contribution from the Z + jets background is estimated from the JZB SFZP neg region after subtracting the contribution from flavor-symmetric backgrounds in this region.

We assign a systematic uncertainty of 25% to JZB SFZP neg and JZB SFZP pos and a systematic uncertainty of 50% to each of the estimates from the three control regions for flavorsymmetric backgrounds.
The background estimation methods are validated in Monte Carlo simulation, in a mix-ture of all SM backgrounds, with and without the inclusion of signal Monte Carlo simulation.
The ratio between observed and predicted distributions is shown in Fig. 2 for the two cases.
There is very good agreement in the background-only hypothesis and good sensitivity to a possible signal.

Simplified model for the production of two gluinos decaying into jets and a Z boson
In the absence of any significant excess, we set upper limits on the production cross-section of simplified models of SUSY (SMS).
In the process considered in this study (shown in Fig. 4), two gluinos are generated, decaying to jets and a neutralino, which in turn decays to a Z boson and the lightest SUSY particle (LSP).
The parameters of the model are the masses of the gluino (mg) and the LSP (mχ0 1 ).
